statement.tex: \\ %text The required integral can be \underline\text{re-written} as \[ \underbrace{\int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}\frac{\sin x}{1+\cos x}\cdot dx}_P + \underbrace{\int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}\frac{x}{1+\cos x}\cdot dx}_Q \] \underline\text{But which of the following is true for P}? %
\\ %text Which of the following is true for \[ \qquad Q = \int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}\frac{x\cdot dx}{1+\cos x} \] %

\\ %text \textbf{Final value? }\underline\text{Given P and Q} (see below) \[ \underbrace{\int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}\frac{\sin x}{1+\cos x}\cdot dx}_P + \underbrace{\int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}\frac{x}{1+\cos x}\cdot dx}_Q \] \underline\text{what is the value of the original integral}? %

reason.tex: \begin{align} P &= \int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}\frac{\sin x}{1+\cos x}\cdot dx \\ \therefore\text{ if }\phi &= 1+\cos x \\ \text{then }d\phi &= -\sin x\cdot dx\implies \sin x\cdot dx = -d\phi \\ \text{and }\phi &= 2\to 1\text{ as }x = 0\to\frac\pi{2}\\ \therefore P &= \underbrace{-\int_2^1\frac{d\phi}\phi = \int_1^2\frac{d\phi}\phi}_{\text{Note the limits}}\\ &= \left[\log\phi\right]_1^2 = \underbrace{\log 2 - \log 1}_{\log 1 = 0} = \log 2 \end{align}
